description.plain:
Ariyan Arslani (stage name Action Bronson) is a rapper from Queens known for his hedonistic lyrics, food references, comically boastful persona, quick temper and live stage antics that include wrestling moves like body slamming members of the audience. His name comes from a combination of his graffiti tagging name (Action) and actor Charles Bronson. He is also known as ‘Bam Bam’ and ‘Bronsoliño’.

After attending culinary school and becoming a well-known fire chef in New York, Bronson decided to focus on his rap career instead after breaking his leg in early 2011, left unable to work for months:

I was arguing with the mother of my children. It was her birthday, and I was cooking for my kids, who were with me at work. I go to carry their food out, and I just slip. Crack. My life changed from that day on.

Bronson released a solo album, a collab album (which reached #13 on Billboard’s Heatseekers Chart) and two mixtapes before Eminem’s manager Paul Rosenberg took him on as a client and got him signed to Vice Records.

His first release after getting signed was the EP Saab Stories, which reached #6 on the US Rap Albums Chart and #63 on the Billboard 200. Bronson’s next mixtape Blue Chips 2 followed soon after and was named one of the best mixtapes of 2013 by Rolling Stone.

In 2015, Bronson released his sophomore album (first on a major label) Mr Wonderful. It went to #7 on the Billboard 200 and its crossover hit “Baby Blue” reached #91 on the Hot 100. His third album Blue Chips 7000 came out two years later and reached #53. 2018’s White Bronco was independently released and did not chart.

Outside of music, Bronson began hosting a food & travel show in 2016 titled Fuck, That’s Delicious, adding the talk show The Untitled Action Bronson Show the following year to his roster. In 2020, Bronson went on a diet that took his weight down from almost 400 pounds to under 300.

Be sure to check out his verified annotations here on Genius.com!

songs.title: Baby Blue

description.plain: Action & Chance The Rapper channel their energy towards jealous women on this soulful ballad. Produced by Mark Ronson, the joint marks the third time Action & Chance have worked together. They previously worked on “NaNa” from Chance’s acclaimed Acid Rap mixtape and the lesser known “Three Course Meal” by ProbCause.

songs.full_title: Easy Rider by Action Bronson
songs.title: Easy Rider

description.plain: “Easy Rider” is Action Bronson’s tale of drugs, status, emotion, and the raw energy he now interprets his life to be, inspired by the 1969 adventure drama of the same name Easy Rider. The song perfectly combines the relaxed and eccentric vibes of the “Flower Power Era” with an exaggerated depiction of Bronson’s past, present, and future. Capping the track, Curt Chambers plays a timeless guitar tribute to the great Jimi Hendrix as Bam Bam rides his Harley of possibility into the waning sunset of definite uncertainty.

description.plain:
Certified Classic:



Fun fact: Harry Fraud sampled Dexter Wansel’s “Rings of Saturn” (1976) for this track. The same sample was also used on Talib Kweli’s “Long Life”.

The title is a reference to the Leonard Cohen song Bird On The Wire.

Also a reference to the Mel Gibson Goldie Hawn film of the same title http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099141/?ref_=nv_sr_1

description.plain:
On February 16th, 2015 Action Bronson released yet another single from his then-upcoming debut album Mr. Wonderful available for download along with the start of the pre-order later that day.

Bronson broke down this song for Complex Magazine:

‘Terry’ is my favorite song on the album. Produced by the Alchemist. We were in a funk for a little bit, so we call it. It wasn’t really a funk whatsoever. We did ‘Big League Chew’ and ‘Terry’ in the same day. ‘Terry’ was the one that got Al out of his quote-unquote beat-making funk. And me just rhyming on that just made me feel like a fucking man. If I heard that beat anywhere else, if anyone else had it, I would be so fucking pissed. I would be heartbroken. I’m just glad that I have that joint. And then that extra piece that comes on the end of it is where we get a little psychedelic and deep. Again, my man Chauncy Sherod is singing ‘What are we waiting for?’ Just giving you a little entrance into opportunity be knocking.

songs.full_title: Pouches of Tuna by Action Bronson (Ft. Roc Marciano)
songs.title: Pouches of Tuna

description.plain:
The first song off Bronson’s Blue Chips mixtape.
The title “Pouches of Tuna” refers to the use of tuna pouches as a standard unit of prison currency now that cigarettes are no longer allowed. So the title means money and the verses are about getting money and living large.

songs.full_title: A Light in the Addict by Action Bronson (Ft. Black Atlass & Party Supplies)
songs.title: A Light in the Addict
songs.title_with_featured: A Light in the Addict (Ft. Black Atlass & Party Supplies)

description.plain:
“A Light in The Addict” was released on October 9th, 2014 via Party Supplies' Soundcloud account. Although Bronson was originally listed as a featured artist, this song would be featured on his album, Mr. Wonderful. Following “Easy Rider”, “The Light in the Addict” is the 2nd release from the album.



Bronson broke down this song for Complex Magazine:

That seamlessly transitions into ‘A Light in the Addict,’ which is an introspective-type thing. I actually wrote it while I was on the plane sitting in first class, feeling like shit. Naturally, you stare out the window, you’re like, ‘Fuck, if we fall….’ You’re always thinking about that shit. So, [I was thinking] if I jump will you feel it when I land? It’s kind of like, would you cry if I died with a belt around my neck? Or would you be like, hell yeah? If you knew that I died from strangulation while fucking would you be happy or would you be sad?

description.plain:
The real star of the show on “Contemporary Man” is producer Party Supplies, who switches up the beat FIVE times! All the beats are popular singles from the 80s.

(0:00) – “Sledgehammer” by Peter Gabriel (1986)
(0:49) – “Sussudio” by Phil Collins (1985)
(1:35) – “Jack and Diane” by John Mellencamp (1982)
(2:02) – “Another Day In Paradise” by Phil Collins (1989)
(2:30) – “I Wonder if I Take You Home” by Lisa Lisa & Cult Jam and Full Force (1985)
(3:23) – “Simple as That” by Huey Lewis and The News (1987)

songs.full_title: The Rising by Action Bronson (Ft. Big Body Bes)
songs.title: The Rising

description.plain:
Bronson broke down this song for Complex Magazine:


This is one of my favorite joints because when you put it on you just wanna throw your head through the wall. It has the beautiful gospel singing on the chorus, it has Body talking shit—he has one of the best verses he’s ever done. I have my man Chauncy Sherod singing the little faint ‘Oh, baby, when I rise….’ It’s a beautiful thing.

When I start off ‘The Rising,’ I want you to think about Terminator when he arrives on Earth. He’s naked in a ball and lightning is striking. It’s a crazy scene, there’s thunder all over, then: ‘I’ve arrived. The Terminator has arrived.’ That’s that song.

songs.full_title: Hookers At The Point by Action Bronson
songs.title: Hookers At The Point

description.plain: The fact that the song is titled “Hookers at the Point” does not mean that he’s only talking about the prostitute. The three different people whose perspectives he spits through (Cyndi, Silk, and Dano) are all hookers in their own right. They’re at “the Point”, which, besides alluding to a physical location, could mean that all three are hookers who are at the point of rock bottom in their lives. Through circumstance and the decisions they’ve made in their lives, the ultimate consequence ends up being that they are hookers at the end of the line, with no way out.

songs.full_title: White Bronco by Action Bronson
songs.title: White Bronco

description.plain:
“White Bronco” is the first single from Action Bronson’s upcoming album of the same name. It was independently released by Bronson, and distributed by EMPIRE.

The track is produced by Buffalo producer Daringer, best known for his work with Shady/Griselda artists Westside Gunn and Conway, and Bronson’s live band The Special Victims Unit.

The song is quintessential Action Bronson, featuring ridiculous boasts, sports references, and mentions of Bronson’s unique fashion style, as well as references to his other endeavors, such as the best-selling Fuck, That’s Delicious cookbook. The instrumental is smooth, old-school boom bap, complimenting Action perfectly.

description.plain: This is a song about Action dropping bars after bars. Put on a 5 minute instrumental and he’ll knock out a rap in one-take. Meaning he will record his verses in one try. We can believe this is true due to the fumbles he makes in 9-24-11 and continues to rap the whole song in one take.
